Title: Bill Nye: Creationism Is Not Appropriate For Children | Big Think
Descript: Creationism Is Not Appropriate For ChildrenWatch the newest video from Big Think: https://bigth.ink/NewVideoJoin Big Think Edge for exclusive videos: https://bigth.ink/Edge---------------------------------------------------------------------------------- OVERVIEWThe school boards around the U.S. who<U+0092>ve decided to teach children creationism, intelligent design, or whatever you choose to call it, are poking a stick in the eye of anyone who hopes to expand our understanding of the world around us. According to Bill Nye, evolution is such a fundamental scientific truth that<U+0085>well, watch.If you dismiss evolution, Nye says, how can you get any of the followup questions right? The massive number of generations required for evolutionary changes make obvious the kind of time involved, lengthening the age of the earth from religion<U+0092>s few thousand years to science<U+0092>s billions of them. And that expanded view, argues Nye, makes so many other things make sense: If we<U+0092>ve only been around a little while, for example, what<U+0092>s the deal with those ancient dinosaur bones and fossils? A belief in deep time is so critical to our understanding of life, the earth, its processes, and the stars above us, that to deny it is to force oneself into settling for ever-more-implausible explanations of what we see around us.What<U+0092>s got Nye even more chagrined is that it<U+0092>s one thing to turn your own back on science, but when you pass that outlook on to your children, what<U+0092>s at risk is nothing less than the creation of a generation whose basic premise<U+0097>creationism<U+0097>leads to and answers that just get wronger and wronger. Brilliant young minds consigned to scientific failure from the start. We<U+0092>d hope for better from educators and parents. Just imagine the things these fresh, inquisitive minds could discover someday.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------- BILL NYEBill Nye, scientist, engineer, comedian, author, and inventor, is a man with a mission: to help foster a scientifically literate society, to help people everywhere understand and appreciate the science that makes our world work. Making science entertaining and accessible is something Bill has been doing most of his life.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ABOUT BIG THINK:Smarter Faster<U+0099>Big Think is the leading source of expert-driven, actionable, educational content -- with thousands of videos, featuring experts ranging from Bill Clinton to Bill Nye, we help you get smarter, faster. Subscribe to learn from top minds like these daily. Get actionable lessons from the world<U+0092>s greatest thinkers & doers. Our experts are either disrupting or leading their respective fields. We aim to help you explore the big ideas and core skills that define knowledge in the 21st century, so you can apply them to the questions and challenges in your own life.Other Frequent contributors include Michio Kaku & Neil DeGrasse Tyson.Michio Kaku Playlist: https://bigth.ink/kakuBill Nye Playlist: https://bigth.ink/BillNyeNeil DeGrasse Tyson Playlist: https://bigth.ink/deGrasseTysonRead more at Bigthink.com for a multitude of articles just as informative and satisfying as our videos. It features insight from many of the most celebrated and intelligent individuals in the world today. Title: Why reading literature is a form of therapy | Lisa New | Big Think Edge
Descript: Reading as TherapyUsing Literature and Poetry as Coping Mechanismswith Lisa NewModerated by Big Think co-founder and president Peter HopkinsTime and again, reading has been shown to make us healthier, smarter, and more empathic. How can we use literature as therapy during this moment of drastic change? In this live session with Harvard literature professor Lisa New, you<U+0092>ll dive into the world of prose and poetry, discovering the answer to questions like: how can I use reading as a coping mechanism? What do I lose when I only watch the movie and ignore the book? And why do people roll their eyes at poetry, anyway? Sheltering in place is the perfect time to reconnect with books and your love of reading.Ask your questions for Lisa New in the live Q&A!---Poems for discussionOne ArtBy Elizabeth Bishophttps://www.poetryfoundation.org/poem...This Your Home NowBy Mark Dotyhttps://poets.org/poem/your-home-now---Elisa New is the director and host of Poetry in America, director of Verse Video Education, and the Powell M. Cabot Professor of American Literature at Harvard University, where she teaches courses in classic American literature from the Puritans through the present day.
